title: Lyme Park Walk Route

images.caption: Lyme Park gardens

images.title: Alan Fleming / Hase Bank Wood, Lyme Park, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Path through the valley at Hase Bank Wood in Lyme Park.

images.title: Raymond Knapman / Lakeside in spring at Lyme Park, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Lakeside in spring at Lyme Park

images.title: John Darch / The Lantern, Lyme Park, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Fine view from The Lantern folly

images.title: Peter Barr / Pool and overhanging tree in Lyme Park, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Pool and overhanging tree in the park. On the centre horizon can just be seen The Cage, which has been a hunting lodge, park-keeper's house, and a lock-up for prisoners.It is a Grade 2* Listed building, constructed in sandstone.

images.title: Gethin Evans / Lyme Park old mill, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The old mill on the Lyme Park estate with the northern edge of the mill pond in the foreground. Part of the building now houses a coffee shop.

images.title: Graham Hogg / Orangery, Lyme Hall, Cheshire, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Orangery, Lyme Hall

images.title: Stephen G Taylor [CC BY-SA 2.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Cage. This building is perched on a hill in the park. It was originally built around 1580 as a hunting lodge where the ladies of the estate could watch the hunt. At night it was used as a banqueting hall. It overlooks the nearby moors and 1,300 acres of park land. In later years it was used as a game keeper's residence and as a jail for poachers.

description: This is a circular walk through the splendid Lyme Park in Disley, Cheshire. Here you can explore the 1,300 acre estate with its resident deer and enjoy fabulous views of the Peak District. There are also tranquil lakes, peaceful woodland walks and an Edwardian rose garden to enjoy. The park may look familiar as it was used for the BBC production of 'Pride and Prejudice'. The walk begins at the park gate near Disley train station, before exploring the most attractive areas of the park and returning to the start point. The Gritstone Trail long distance path passes through the park so you could pick this up to extend your walk. Heading south will take you towards Bollington via Sponds Hill. Additionally the North Cheshire Way passes through Lyme Park, so you could pick this up and head west towards the village of Adlington, passing the Macclesfield Canal on the way.
